description:
Anabaena azotica SJ-1 is a species of cyanobacteria, also known as blue-green algae, that was isolated from a soil sample collected in Sichuan, China. Cyanobacteria are a group of prokaryotic organisms that are capable of performing oxygenic photosynthesis, similar to plants and algae.

Anabaena azotica SJ-1 is a filamentous cyanobacterium, meaning it forms long chains or filaments of cells. The cells within the filament are typically cylindrical in shape and contain gas vesicles, which allow the organism to regulate its buoyancy in aquatic environments.

This particular strain, SJ-1, has been found to possess the ability to fix atmospheric nitrogen, converting it into a form that can be utilized by the cyanobacterium and potentially other organisms in the surrounding environment. This nitrogen-fixing capability is an important ecological function of certain cyanobacteria species.

Anabaena azotica SJ-1 has been the subject of research, particularly in the field of bioremediation, as it has shown the potential to remove heavy metals and other pollutants from contaminated environments. Additionally, its nitrogen-fixing abilities make it a potential candidate for use in agricultural applications, such as improving soil fertility.
